metadata.title: Doubly Robust Bayesian Inference for Non-Stationary Streaming Data with $\beta$-Divergences
metadata.author: Jeremias Knoblauch, Jack E. Jewson, Theodoros Damoulas
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We present the very first robust Bayesian Online Changepoint Detection algorithm through General Bayesian Inference (GBI) with β-divergences. The resulting inference procedure is doubly robust for both the parameter and the changepoint (CP) posterior, with linear time and constant space complexity. We provide a construction for exponential models and demonstrate it on the Bayesian Linear Regression model. In so doing, we make two additional contributions: Firstly, we make GBI scalable using Structural Variational approximations that are exact as β → 0. Secondly, we give a principled way of choosing the divergence parameter β by minimizing expected predictive loss on-line. Reducing False Discovery Rates of CPS from up to 99% to 0% on real world data, this offers the state of the art.

highlights: Modeling non-stationary time series with changepoints (CPS) is popular [23, 50, 33] and important in a wide variety of research fields, including genetics [8, 16, 42], finance [27], oceanography [24], brain imaging and cognition [13, 20], cybersecurity [37] and robotics [2, 26]
We extend the latter branch of research by deploying Structural Variational Inference (SVI)

We show that standard Bayesian On-line Changepoint Detection breaks down in the M-open world whilst β-D yields useful inference by analyzing noisy measurements of Nitrogen Oxide (NOX) levels in London
This paper has presented the very first robust Bayesian on-line changepoint (CP) detection algorithm and the first ever scalable General Bayesian Inference (GBI) method

While CP detection is a particularly salient example of unaddressed heterogeneity and outliers leading to poor inference, the capabilities of General Bayesian Inference and the Structural Variational approximations presented extend far beyond this setting

We give a particularly striking demonstration of the inferential power that can be unlocked through divergence-based General Bayesian inference.

key_statements: Modeling non-stationary time series with changepoints (CPS) is popular [23, 50, 33] and important in a wide variety of research fields, including genetics [8, 16, 42], finance [27], oceanography [24], brain imaging and cognition [13, 20], cybersecurity [37] and robotics [2, 26]
In addressing misspecification and outliers this way, our approach builds on the principles of General Bayesian Inference (GBI) [see 6, 21] and robust divergences [e.g. 4, 15]
Within Bayesian On-line Changepoint Detection, we propose to scale Structural Variational Inference using variance-reduced Stochastic Gradient Descent

Section 5 showcases the substantial gains in performance of robust Bayesian On-line Changepoint Detection when compared to its standard version on real world data in terms of both predictive error and CP detection.
2 Using Bayesian On-line Changepoint Detection with β-Divergences
We extend the latter branch of research by deploying Structural Variational Inference (SVI)

In the Bayesian On-line Changepoint Detection setting, there is an obvious trade-off between accuracy and scalability: Since the posterior predictive distributions fmt, rt) for all run-lengths rt drive CP detection, Stochastic Gradient Descent estimates are insufficiently accurate for small run-lengths rt
We show how robust Bayesian On-line Changepoint Detection deals with outliers on the well-log data set

We show that standard Bayesian On-line Changepoint Detection breaks down in the M-open world whilst β-D yields useful inference by analyzing noisy measurements of Nitrogen Oxide (NOX) levels in London
Detailed information is provided in the Appendix

Software and simulation code is available as part of a reproducibility award at https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/rbocpdms/.
5.1
This paper has presented the very first robust Bayesian on-line changepoint (CP) detection algorithm and the first ever scalable General Bayesian Inference (GBI) method

While CP detection is a particularly salient example of unaddressed heterogeneity and outliers leading to poor inference, the capabilities of General Bayesian Inference and the Structural Variational approximations presented extend far beyond this setting

We give a particularly striking demonstration of the inferential power that can be unlocked through divergence-based General Bayesian inference.

summary: Modeling non-stationary time series with changepoints (CPS) is popular [23, 50, 33] and important in a wide variety of research fields, including genetics [8, 16, 42], finance [27], oceanography [24], brain imaging and cognition [13, 20], cybersecurity [37] and robotics [2, 26].

Standard Bayesian inference minimizes the Kullback-Leibler divergence (KLD) between the fitted model and the Data Generating Mechanism (DGM), but is not robust under outliers or model misspecification due to its strictly increasing influence function.
In addressing misspecification and outliers this way, our approach builds on the principles of General Bayesian Inference (GBI) [see 6, 21] and robust divergences [e.g. 4, 15].
Section 5 showcases the substantial gains in performance of robust BOCPD when compared to its standard version on real world data in terms of both predictive error and CP detection.
Standard Bayesian inference minimizes the KLD between the Data Generating Mechanism (DGM) and its probabilistic model.
Modeling et as Student’s t under the KLD lets νt dominate parameter inference and lets 1% of observations inflate the predictive variance substantially.
This is why using the Student’s t error for the BLR model with standard Bayes will not provide robust run-length posteriors: While an outlying observation yt+1 will have greater density f KLD

In the BOCPD setting, there is an obvious trade-off between accuracy and scalability: Since the posterior predictive distributions fmt, rt) for all run-lengths rt drive CP detection, SGD estimates are insufficiently accurate for small run-lengths rt.
The resulting on-line inference has constant space and linear time complexity like SGD, but produces good estimates for small rt and converges faster [22, 29, 30].
With M containing one BLR model of form yt = μ + εt, Figure 4 shows that robust BOCPD deals with outliers on-line.

The example in Fig. 1 B gives an illustration of the importance of robustness in medium-dimensional (BOCPD) problems: It suffices for a single dimension of the problem to be misspecified or outlierprone for inference to fail.
Both methods find a change in dynamics after the congestion charge introduction, but variance in the model posterior is substantially lower for the robust algorithm.
This paper has presented the very first robust Bayesian on-line changepoint (CP) detection algorithm and the first ever scalable General Bayesian Inference (GBI) method.

While CP detection is a particularly salient example of unaddressed heterogeneity and outliers leading to poor inference, the capabilities of GBI and the Structural Variational approximations presented extend far beyond this setting.

We give a particularly striking demonstration of the inferential power that can be unlocked through divergence-based General Bayesian inference
headline: We present the very first robust Bayesian Online Changepoint Detection algorithm through General Bayesian Inference  with β-divergences
